noun.description: The process by which different kinds of living organisms are thought to have developed and diversified from earlier forms during the history of the earth.
The gradual development of something, especially from a simple to a more complex form.
examples: the forms of written languages undergo constant evolution

noun.description: The giving off of a gaseous product, or of heat.
A pattern of movements or maneuvers.
examples: silk ribbons waving in fanciful evolutions

noun.description: The extraction of a root from a given quantity.

origin: Early 17th century: from Latin evolutio(n-) unrolling, from the verb evolvere (see evolve). Early senses related to movement, first recorded in describing a wheeling maneuver in the realignment of troops or ships. Current senses stem from a notion of opening out, giving rise to the sense development.
